AUP IT Day 2019

Rules

Mechanics

Criteria

Reward and Compensation

Access officers are not allowed to join the contest.

The participant must be enrolled in the course CBIT 212 (Professional Elective I)

The participant must have a Github repository for his/her website.

The participant’s website must contain mostly original content.

The participant can include a BLOG or a PERSONAL PORTFOLIO.

There are two elimination rounds.

1st elimination round – Basic website (can just be a skeleton) should be deployed by Thursday night, 7:30pm with the repository name “access-portfolio” (e.g., www.github.com/USERNAME/access-portfolio).

2nd elimination round – The near-finished website should be deployed by Wednesday evening (November 20). The criteria is listed on the section.

Content – 20%. Students should include relevant and accurate information. The use of placeholders and copy-pasted content will cause some deductions to the participant’s score. Additional content about the participant’s hobbies, etc. will be a plus.

Structure and Navigation – 20%. The participant should ensure that the user of the website can easily and properly navigate the website.

Animations and Transitions – 20%. The participant must attract the user, not only through the layout and design of the website, but also through the visual effects of it.

Interactivity – 20%. The participant should engage the user to do more than just scrolling and reading through the webpage.

Originality – 20%. The participant should not make his/her website look generic and bland. The use of CSS frameworks is discouraged, but is allowed as long as the user maintains his/her style and originality. The use of templates derived online is strictly prohibited.


Additional points are conferred to websites that exhibit:

  • Responsiveness – scales well across device categories
  • Accessibility and Readability – the website can be read properly
  • Exceptional artistic style – e.g., minimalism, pop-art
  • Compliance to coding conventions and web design trends

There will only be 5-10 websites to be presented at the IT Day website exhibit. There will probably be a consolation prize or some other form of compensation for other participants who did not win.

A cash prize (amount to be announced soon) will be given to the winner of the contest. Participants who are not eliminated will earn additional points for the Professional Elective 2 class.
